YV3DQKIRR6KLX5LWTWPZHJMMTY.body: Tesla is headed for a disaster. It's lineup of electric cars is about to become ordinary, common place. The competition is bringing out the same product, and probably for less cost. But it's the future that drives Tesla stock, especially the fully autonomous dream, of Tesla owners letting their cars roam free, picking up strays who are not so fortunate as to own a Musk-mobile. But that is a false dream. Instead, Alphabet, Amazon, and Apple - which are developing real autonomous vehicles that will be able to navigate city streets at 35 mph and not just parking lot maneuvers at 2 mph - will populate the cities with their autonomous corporate owned fleets, putting a dagger into the heart of Tesla hype. Indeed, Musk made a fool's errand by declaring his approach with cameras and radar as sufficient when it is only good for second-rate driver's assist and parking lot maneuvers. So he is so far behind of the curve in the development of the necessary LIDAR technology that he cannot catch up - indeed, he doesn't even realize the need - well, at this point he probably does but he knows it's too late in the game to change his approach so he might as well hype his infallibility to milk his dead-end approach as much as possible before he is discovered by the fawning masses. This is why Tesla stock will essentially disappear once these tech behemoths, with tens of thousands of world-class scientists and engineers working on the problem, flood the streets with their truly autonomous ride service fleets.

2LL4TVKL6DKXJHPBQRT74F5BRU.body: Look, I'm a former broker at Merrill.  I'm not trying to troll anyone or any side long or short.  This stock is on my watchlist.  If you are long, take you profits and be happy.  What you don't get about mania is that in order to actually REALIZE a gain, you have to eventually sell.  However, in "mania bubbles" like this, the more the stock goes up, the more reluctant you will be to sell, convinced you are going to realize exponential gains.  And so, you'll hang on for just one day too long.  It happens every time.  And then, when it turns, you'll convince yourself that it's a temporary hiccup, that you'll get your money back, so you hold.  And you lose everything.  If you're long and in the money, take your profits now and be happy, not greedy.  So what if you miss some upside?  NOBODY gets out at the top.  You will, however, miss the crash.  And it will crash.

2LL4TVKL6DKXJHPBQRT74F5BRU.body: Look, I'm a former broker at Merrill.  I'm not trying to troll anyone or any side long or short.  This stock is on my watchlist.  If you are long, take you profits and be happy.  What you don't get about mania is that in order to actually REALIZE a gain, you have to eventually sell.  However, in "mania bubbles" like this, the more the stock goes up, the more reluctant you will be to sell, convinced you are going to realize exponential gains.  And so, you'll hang on for just one day too long.  It happens every time.  And then, when it turns, you'll convince yourself that it's a temporary hiccup, that you'll get your money back, so you hold.  And you lose everything.  If you're long and in the money, take your profits now and be happy, not greedy.  So what if you miss some upside?  NOBODY gets out at the top.  You will, however, miss the crash.  And it will crash.

RNENY57BMRP43DF6KOK36CDFSA.body:
Advocates of Tesla frequently make disparaging comparisons to Ford as a means to downplay Tesla's use of leverage (debt).  Those comparisons ignore that Ford earns an arbitrage return on most of its debt by lending money to buyers and lessees of Ford products.  Net earnings on Ford Credit's lending operation exceeds net earnings from manufacture, sale and leasing of cars and trucks.

A few comparisons are in order.

In 2020Q1 Tesla reported the following liabilities

Current portion of debt and finance leases : $3,217 millions
Debt and finance leases, net of current portion : $10,666 millions

Total reported debt : $13,883 millions  

Ford reported :

Current portion of debt in support of manufacturing : $1,609 millions
Current portion of debt in support of Ford Credit : $51,303 millions

Long term portion of debt in support of manufacturing : $28,411 millions
Long term portion of debt in support of Ford Credit : $85,533 millions.

Tesla does not separately call out how much was borrowed to finance leasing.  The best indicator is Tesla reports an asset value of $2,527 millions for leased vehicles.  Presumably, the unpaid / unexpensed portion of money borrowed to finance leased vehicles does not exceed the current asset value of $2,527 millions unless Tesla is upside-down on leased cars.

As an estimate, $11,356 millions of Tesla's $13,883 millions in debt is in support of manufacturing operations.  That would include money spent to build Gigafactories.

By itself that is neither bad nor good.  It may be a prudent use of capital if a return is earned on capital assets  which exceeds the cost of capital used to acquire those assets.

Most of Ford's debt earns an arbitrage return by borrowing at lower wholesale rates and lending at higher retail rates to buyers and lessees of Ford products.  Only $30,020 millions of $166,856 millions in debt is used to support manufacturing operations.  The remaining $136,836 millions is not tied up in manufacturing plants and equipment.  Over 80% of Ford's outstanding debt would gradually be extinguished if Ford were to shut down Ford Credit by making no new loans and using revenues from existing loans and leasses to pay down $136 billion in debt.

Proportionately Ford has $30 billion in borrowed money tied up in plant and equipment to Tesla's $11 billion in order to produce five to six million units annually.  That is about ten to twelve times the number of cars produced by Tesla in its peak year to date.

Ford's use of borrowed capital is more efficient than Tesla's in production of cars and trucks.

Tesla reported revenue of $239 million on leasing of cars in 2020Q1 with cost of goods sold of $122 million for a margin of 95.9%.  Using a figure of $2,527 millions of borrowed capital in support of leases that is a return of 4.63% ($117 / $2,527) on borrowed capital.  That appears to be a respectable return as the coupon rate on Tesla's bond borrowings is lower.  It is not reported how much that return is reduced by the portion of SG&A expense attributable to the leasing unit.

For comparison, in 2020Q1 Ford Credit reported net operating income of $43 million  on revenue of $2,967 millions. Net income from Ford Credit was insufficient to offset Ford's losses on selling cars and trucks.

A year earlier, Ford Credit posted net income of $742 millions on loan revenues of $3,097 millions.   Net income from Ford Credit exceeded net income of $454 million from selling cars and trucks.  Ford Credit uses OPM to earn money for Ford shareholders.  The arbitrage return on borrowed money is comparable to the return earned on deposits at a large bank.

There is little reason for Ford to shutdown Ford Credit.

RNENY57BMRP43DF6KOK36CDFSA.body:
Advocates of Tesla frequently make disparaging comparisons to Ford as a means to downplay Tesla's use of leverage (debt).  Those comparisons ignore that Ford earns an arbitrage return on most of its debt by lending money to buyers and lessees of Ford products.  Net earnings on Ford Credit's lending operation exceeds net earnings from manufacture, sale and leasing of cars and trucks.

A few comparisons are in order.

In 2020Q1 Tesla reported the following liabilities

Current portion of debt and finance leases : $3,217 millions
Debt and finance leases, net of current portion : $10,666 millions

Total reported debt : $13,883 millions  

Ford reported :

Current portion of debt in support of manufacturing : $1,609 millions
Current portion of debt in support of Ford Credit : $51,303 millions

Long term portion of debt in support of manufacturing : $28,411 millions
Long term portion of debt in support of Ford Credit : $85,533 millions.

Tesla does not separately call out how much was borrowed to finance leasing.  The best indicator is Tesla reports an asset value of $2,527 millions for leased vehicles.  Presumably, the unpaid / unexpensed portion of money borrowed to finance leased vehicles does not exceed the current asset value of $2,527 millions unless Tesla is upside-down on leased cars.

As an estimate, $11,356 millions of Tesla's $13,883 millions in debt is in support of manufacturing operations.  That would include money spent to build Gigafactories.

By itself that is neither bad nor good.  It may be a prudent use of capital if a return is earned on capital assets  which exceeds the cost of capital used to acquire those assets.

Most of Ford's debt earns an arbitrage return by borrowing at lower wholesale rates and lending at higher retail rates to buyers and lessees of Ford products.  Only $30,020 millions of $166,856 millions in debt is used to support manufacturing operations.  The remaining $136,836 millions is not tied up in manufacturing plants and equipment.  Over 80% of Ford's outstanding debt would gradually be extinguished if Ford were to shut down Ford Credit by making no new loans and using revenues from existing loans and leasses to pay down $136 billion in debt.

Proportionately Ford has $30 billion in borrowed money tied up in plant and equipment to Tesla's $11 billion in order to produce five to six million units annually.  That is about ten to twelve times the number of cars produced by Tesla in its peak year to date.

Ford's use of borrowed capital is more efficient than Tesla's in production of cars and trucks.

Tesla reported revenue of $239 million on leasing of cars in 2020Q1 with cost of goods sold of $122 million for a margin of 95.9%.  Using a figure of $2,527 millions of borrowed capital in support of leases that is a return of 4.63% ($117 / $2,527) on borrowed capital.  That appears to be a respectable return as the coupon rate on Tesla's bond borrowings is lower.  It is not reported how much that return is reduced by the portion of SG&A expense attributable to the leasing unit.

For comparison, in 2020Q1 Ford Credit reported net operating income of $43 million  on revenue of $2,967 millions. Net income from Ford Credit was insufficient to offset Ford's losses on selling cars and trucks.

A year earlier, Ford Credit posted net income of $742 millions on loan revenues of $3,097 millions.   Net income from Ford Credit exceeded net income of $454 million from selling cars and trucks.  Ford Credit uses OPM to earn money for Ford shareholders.  The arbitrage return on borrowed money is comparable to the return earned on deposits at a large bank.

There is little reason for Ford to shutdown Ford Credit.

FNN5FWIGYMSCUTVFO4V5U7HQKQ.body:
The psychology of trading in this market is just not anything we ever learned to deal with as investors. I have been trading for over 20 years and a lot of what I was taught 20 years ago just doesn't apply these days. There are so many factors driving up companies like Tesla. The average investor does not look at profitability, charts, technicals, fundamentals, etc.. They look at the future of America and the world. Where are we headed 5 to 10 to 20 years down the road. Day to day things like Covid, unemployment, etc.. don't matter anymore in a market like this. We freaked out on Feb. and March and we now realize that we had no reason to. This virus, like all other viruses, will eventually be dealt with and we will move on back to normal life. 

Besides all of that, on a technical level of trading, we have zero commission trades now, which years ago did not exist and would cost anywhere from $5 up to $20 to make a trade. Now we can day trade the same stock 100 times a day with no cost to us. Plus we have the Robinhooders and the millennials that buy into companies like hertz and jc penny and make tons of money and then lose tons of money. 20 years ago, people did not invest in bankrupt companies. Today is a whole new ball game. Tesla might be in a bubble, but it might not burst for a month or a year or 5 years or 10 years or never. Look at Amazon as a pure example of people talking about a bubble. They were saying that back when it was under $1000/share. If people listened to the hysteria of the "Bubble on Amazon", and sold, they would have missed out on tripling their value. Tesla is not just an EV car company. It is so much more to the people of the world. It stands for great achievement and smarts and a whole new way of life. People invest in those types of company. Elon Musk is a genius on many levels and it is his genius that will keep this company flying high for a long long long time.
